questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, presents to the clinic for her first antenatal appointment at 6 weeks of estimated gestational age. She is asymptomatic and feels well. Past medical history is notable for sickle cell disease, managed with hydroxyurea, as well as an uncomplicated vaginal delivery two years ago. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mmHg. On physical exam, the patient is in no distress. The uterus is mildly enlarged, and the pelvis is normal. Screening laboratory results are shown in the table below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Serum chemistries           
 Hemoglobin      10.1 g/dL     
 Hematocrit      31 %     
 Leukocyte count      7,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      227,000/mm3     
 Mean corpuscular volume      77 fL     
 Serum ferritin      normal     
 Total-iron-binding capacity      normal
questions.solution:
This pregnant patient with sickle cell disease should be treated with high-dose folic acid supplementation. In patients with sickle cell disease, the abnormal hemoglobin, known as hemoglobin S (HbS), causes red blood cells to bend into an abnormal sickled shape that is easily destroyed. To compensate, red cell production is increased, which leads to depletion of folic acid stores. Folic acid is critical for normal fetal development, especially early in gestation during development of the neural tube. For this reason, pregnant patients with SCD require high-dose folic acid supplementation during pregnancy.        

Hemoglobinopathies are associated with multiple increased risks during pregnancy. Therefore, prenatal management is more intense and more frequent than when caring for non-affected individuals. The risks and associated management recommendations for severe hemoglobinopathies are detailed in the table above.       

Option Analysis

✅ High-dose folic acid supplementation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Iron supplementation:
Incorrect: This patient’s anemia is secondary to sickle cell disease (SCD) rather than iron deficiency anemia, given her known SCD and normal iron labs. She is at greater risk of transfusion-related iron overload rather than iron deficiency and should not have supplemental iron. 
❌ Increased hydroxyurea dose:
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea is teratogenic and can lead to congenital anomalies and pregnancy loss. Instead of increasing the hydroxyurea dose, the risks and benefits of decreasing the dose or discontinuing hydroxyurea should be discussed with the patient at this time. 
❌ Exchange transfusion:
Incorrect: An exchange transfusion may be appropriate in patients with sickle cell disease experiencing a pain crisis that does not respond to more conservative management. In an exchange transfusion, the abnormal sickled cells causing the vasoocclusions are removed while unaffected blood is transfused into the patient. This patient is not having a pain crisis. 
❌ Iron chelation therapy:
Incorrect: Iron chelation therapy is indicated in patients with severe thalassemias or in patients with sickle cell disease who have transfusion-related iron overload. With thalassemias, abnormal intracellular inclusions of clumped excess globin chains weaken the red cell membranes, leading to intravascular hemolysis and iron overload.
